If I can save just one person from this horrible career mistake the time it took to write this would be worth it!!!!

review_title: First Aid & Safety Service Sales Representative (SSR)
job_title: First Aid & Safety Service Sales Representative (SSR) in Norcross, GA
pros: “Weekends off but I'd rather work weekends ALL YEAR LONG + HOLIDAYS after working here. THIS PLACE IS NOT A GOOD PLACE TO WORK ESPECIALLY IF YOU ARE TRYING TO TAKE CARE OF A FAMILY BASED ON THE LOW INCOME HERE.
cons:
“Commission structure is ridiculous in regards to the pay out and how much we make them. The base salary that they promise you is NOT CORRECT SO ASK MANY MANY MANY questions about what it is WITHOUT commissions. They will try to push that with the commission you will make a certain amount which by the time you follow Alice into the rabbit hole you are in to deep and that there is very little grass on the other side of the fence. Literally I had paychecks that made me feel like i worked at MCDONALD'S and wondered how i was gonna pay my bills. Sales reps are constantly opening accounts that are not suited for a service agreement they just use the SSR in their pawn to make there money by haggling the customer on pricing to win the business. If priced to low you will be nothing more than a glorified delivery girl or boy, and very rarely are the accounts sold at the top tier pricing which nets you the most commission . Also I had to close numerous accounts due to the customer not paying their bills due to the way the Sales Rep set the account up with inaccurate payment information or the person in charge of that company to pay the bills. Also had to close other account because the customer never wanted or needed service. There were times I actually called random peoples houses because the Sales Rep just put a random contact number in the system just to open the account on the premise they'll fix it later, never happened. They were never held accountable for any mishaps everything was a dumping ground to the SSR. Sad part is Management is suppose to approve or disapprove every account being opened, however when the mentality of management is that they will protect their monthly and yearly bonus BY ANY MEANS NECESSARY its a breeding ground for an US vs THEM face off which is sadly the current state of this First Aid and Safety division. Management here DOES NOT CARE ABOUT employees as they say. Even corporate upper management hires managers from the outside and the whole time i was there NO ONE was ever promoted from SSR up into Management. They say they like to promote from within but that is very false and untrue. However they will dangle that carrot in front of you to make you work harder and never give it to you. If you ever wondered how a PACK MULE felt then APPLY HERE. Everyone is just a number that can be replaced. Voicing your view is looked down on if its not that of management even though they preach the company stands on integrity and honor but yet dosen't value that opinion of those like the SSR on the front line. Be prepared for the most UNDERHANDED and DISCOURAGING business practices to be on full display here. The most important thing anyone gets from a job is a paycheck to provide and take care of their family and once that line is crossed, blurred, or just plain out obliterated then all integrity and validity is out the room. The goals they have you work so hard to chase every month can be gone in a instant of achieving said goal because management will issue credits for those accounts that have not paid their bills months ago and WILL TAKE THE COMMISSION BACK FROM YOUR CURRENT PAYCHECK SOMETIMES WITHOUT WARNING OR A CLEAR EXPLANATION AS TO WHY and also THEY WILL TAKE AWAY from the amount of sales you worked so hard to achieve during the month and this is SADLY AND DISCOURAGINGLY DONE ON THE LAST DAY OF THE MONTH. So example if your goal is $20,000 and they credit $2,000 against that then you just LOST YOUR COMMISSION (Taken from next check) AND YOU MISSED YOUR KPI GOAL all in one click WITHOUT WARNING. THEY NEVER EVER KEPT US IN THE LOOP about credits they would send out a mass email stating certain accounts will be getting credited on the LAST DAY OF THE MONTH AND IT WAS 95% of the time between the hours of 3-5pm. Therefore there is no way you can go out and sell $2000 dollars to put you back in the clear. Then because you did not obtain a certain amount of KPI's they will have a performance review and ask why you are not hitting goals but seem to skip over the fact that your sales just got HIJACKED days prior. DO NOT ---DO NOT----- DO NOT trust Human Resources here who claims they have an open door policy more like an BIG OPEN MOUTH policy as they frequent lunch with management partners on a constant basis. I know you're thinking its a harmless business lunch until you find out that what was discussed by you in confidentiality was being told to that person and used against you. The famous phrase "TRUST NO ONE" fully describes the HR staff here. Many SSR's had to utilize the anonymous number to voice their opinion because of the BLATANT FRATERNIZING between HR and management. Sad to say I was actually warned about this my first week on the job.

cons:
God..where to start.

As a graduate program expecting to attract top talent the promises made come no where near close to matching reality. Expect to be getting your hands very dirty, tons of manual work, long hours, pointless and rather tedious tasks are the absolute norm. review_title: First Aid & Safety Stay away if you don't want sheer frustration in your life!
pros: The customers you deal with on a daily basis were great. Working on your own (pros & cons)
cons:
One of the most frustrating and difficult companies to work for. You were expected to do everything on your own. No support except from the other SSR's (Sales & Service Reps). You were told in the interview their would be support but not from management. There was constant change from what was told at the onset of the position to what was expected. If you are a good liar and want to sell customers products they don't want and can be sneaky and fill their cabinets then you could make good money. If you are pushy and enjoy being overloaded with what you are expected to do  and know then you will enjoy this environment. 

You are given ride along training and every SSR is different with how they train. They make it appear as an easy job start at 8:30 - 9 and finish 2:30 - 3:30 depending on the SSR. Well once they give you your van everything changes. You are expected to go through the van yourself and figure out what inventory you have. You are given a PRC and expected to follow what is scheduled for you without being able to provide your input in order to make your route more effective. You may or may not have the correct catalogues you need to know all of the products you are expected to sell and you are definitely not given any training on the products once again this is something you are expected to do your self. 

Basically it is figure it out yourself but don't expect to get any support from management as all they do is tell you you need to sell this and then they add more products, more customers and no input from yourself in order to make your route more efficient. You are to follow what is called a PRC device which has your customers and daily service route in it. These as well are very dated technology which crashes all of the time which then you are expected to go to a manual service - which you may or may not have been explained this.

They pay - start base $40K you then have the opportunity to go on bas $311/week + commission if you upsell the first aid (stuff customers don't need) and safety products. Most people stay on the base as the company makes it a challenge to earn enough to make the $311+ commission to live.

If you are desperate for a job then go ahead and apply if you enjoy sheer frustration and no support, if you enjoy the challenge of dated technology that you are expected to rely on then apply for a position with First Aid & safety. If you enjoy being left out on your own to figure things out and learn products on your own then this is the job for you. Otherwise be forewarned this is one of the most frustrating jobs I have ever had.

pros: Looks great on a resume. Benefits are good. 401k is good too. Great entry level experience for recent college graduates
cons: You are promised the world but will cap out. Depending on your location, micro management very much exists. If you are able to relocate, you have a better chance of being promoted.

review_title: High Turnover Tells All About Cintas
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Denver, CO
pros: 4 day work week, that's it!
cons:
Honesty and Integrity are what this company claims to stand  for are nothing more than something you hear on the Cintas TV they make you watch each month.  In reality, many times trucks are only loaded at 70%-80% full though customer is charged full amount.  (My manager actually told us to make up statistics of how much we could save customers if they would sign a service agreement).

Most managers are hired directly from military or college and it is evident they have little managerial experience.  if you have any manager experience elsewhere, they will not hire you.  They train all new managers "Cintas' way".  It is extremely frustrating because they just end up  repeating the same things that they read in trainings verses really thinking it through.  They tell you to run the route like your own business but micromanage to the smallest detail.  They ask  your feedback, but will use it against you as being negative if not what they want to hear

Extremely high employee turnover rate really says it all.  If this was a good job, people would be sticking around!  An example:  In just over two years of my employment,  only 25% of SSR employees are still here.  Out of 4 service managers that were here when I started, only 1 is still here.

There are way too many sales contests, sometimes 4 going on all at the same time.  Compensation is low for these contests, too. Sales goals are unrealistic, and continue to get worse as you do better.

Too many meetings (ex:  weekly debriefs, weekly team meetings, weekly sales quota debrief, monthly location meeting, sales contest meetings, quarterly safety meeting, and online trainings).

Everything is one sided with Cintas:  They sign one sided service agreements with customers that will lock them into 5 years of service, then they will systematically increase the price at least 2 times a year. If you lose an account because management doubled price, it's your fault.  If you are unable to resign a new agreement with a customer before their agreement ends, it will go against you on your review and your monthly commission.

Company does not embrace new technology so there is incredible amount of paperwork that must be filled out, signed off on, reviewed, and ultimately entered into the system.  Also, safety is toted as number one but is really just lip-service as many times you may not have a cart to transport materials into customers, vehicle fleet is not properly maintained.

Lack of communication between departments which needs to poor experience to the customer, and frustration to employees as they many times have to do it all just to make sure it gets done.  

No paid holidays if you have 4 day work schedule.

pros:

cons:

cons: The pay scale is crazy low! Not enough woman being promoted into management positions. It's more of a "boys club". Where I was there was no real room for growth.

pros: You get the opportunity to be so micromanaged you dont have to be good at all to make sales. Other companies love taking Cintas employees bc they know if you can put up with that BS you can kill it in any other job that has great work/life balance with much better pay that does not require you to sell toilet paper/install it yourself/ deliver it yourself/ and collect bills yourself/ or they wont pay you on the account.
cons: Where to begin....first they will raise your number so high the expections are impossible to meet which is why turnover is rampant. They pit you against others on your team to steal accounts do whatever bc it does not effect your managers number at all so they encourage it. Your work life balance does not exist. You will work 60 hours a week due to the ridiculous amount of paperwork bc you have to have people sign 5 year contracts for toilet paper on top of getting it approved by your manager, your director, your GM, your service team, even your driver. They expect you to grind yourself into the ground with promises of promotions that never come due to spots dont open up. If a team struggles they just fire sales guys not the managers. They lose all their top performers after year or two to take much better jobs. They cant keep anyone valuable bc after a little time people see the real inner workings and its completely different that portrayed through interview process. This is a great job if you like busting your backside while your manager sits at home and asks you to take a picture outside your window immediately and send it back to make sure your knocking on doors at 7am rain or shine. Not to mention sitting in a cubicle twice a week for 5 hours makeing phon3 calls nonstop. If you dont you get scolded by your manager who just stands there and says keep going you get a bathroom break only last 5 min each hour. Not to mention everything your selling 90 percent of the population does not care to listen to your speech and your usually 50% more expensive than anyone else. Sounds great right?

review_title: Terrible job for a sales person!
pros: Amazing car package. $355 for the car, $54 for maintenance and $50 for your own cellphone. They also put your car in a lease back program, which means they lost you under their insurance. Be warned that limits what you are allowed to do with YOUR car. They also pay for your gas (if you get 24mpg) with a company credit card. Make sure you get the cheapest gas around though.
cons: They are hands down the cheapest company out there. They refuse to use the AC is the summer so the office is hot! If you leave a light on the whole office gets an email calling you out. They will not spend money on keeping office equipment current. They give you an old beat up tablet style hp with a broken CRM. The sales process is dirty because you promise the world and cannot deliver a sandwich. Service will screw up about 90% of your installs, which makes you look foolish in front of your customer. You will have plenty of days where you have to ride on trucks picking up dirty uniforms and bar towels. Those days about 25 -35 per year you have to be at the plant for 5 am. The trucks are usually old and without AC as well. On Monday and Wednesday you have to be at the plant for 7 am for a meeting then to make 200 cold calls for the week. You cannot leave until you make 8 appts each day. Most people are so sick of you calling they just hang up. The "Golden Hours" are 7:30-5:30.  That means you must be in your territory those hours. You MUST have 16+ new presentations each week or you will be put on plan. During the interview process they make a lot of empty promises, such as getting you out of training early, or you'll make commission on everything you sell. They will also talk about bonuses that can get up to $30k quarterly (still haven't seen anyone get that). While you're an SRT the other rep that is sharing your territory is getting bonuses off of everything you sell. They are incentivized for your sales. They say this makes them help you, but what I have noticed is it makes them give you all the customers they don't want but still get paid for selling them. You have to go thru a mandatory 12 weeks of training where you will make little to no money at all. You will not be able to get on the auto package until you graduate training. While in training you are the managers secretary.  Loading trucks, counting uniforms, doing fitting events, and working in the plant sorting nasty smelly maggot infested bar towels. Do not fall for the empty promises. RUN AWAY AND RUN FAST!!!

review_title: Okay to work for but shady business practices
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Franklin, WI
pros: Decent pay for sales and service, four day work week, and no weekends.
cons: It's sales, so they have the sales team do some iffy things to get the business. Large companies are treated like gold while small mom and pop are nickeled and dimed every chance they get. KPI's are impossible to hit unless you have a route specifically built to hit them.

review_title: management can be hit or miss
pros: Great company, most employees at the customer-facing level are great people to work with.
cons: management can be fantastic or absolutely terrible. It depends on the location and the manager, and upper management doesn't seem to listen to the concerns of employees when lower management is causing problems.

pros: Overall a strong company that's not going anywhere. Solid commission and bonus plan along with good benefits and descent car package. Only 2 half days spent in the office per week. Ability to adjust product pricing to be competitive against competition.
cons:
Corporate beyond belief. Sales and service do not mesh, and might as well be two different companies. Micromanagement, micromanagement, micromanagement. Expect to spend more time filling out sales reports, activity reports, doing field rides with management, and doing contract paperwork rather than selling. Even field rides with prospective new hires are a way they try to micromanage you and try to catch you not following the activity model.

Phone calls and cold calls are endless, and your expected to close 3/4 new businesses per week to hit your numbers... which is doable, but often times you can't always sign up high quality business that are going to pay their bills at that rate and you end up signing up businesses that are going to be problematic 3 months down the road. It's very much a what have you done for me lately mentality, and don't expect to have any growth opportunities unless you drink the Kool Aid and lie about sales activity and pretend like there are no issues that need to be dealt with. 

The more you sell the more fires you put out. Be prepared to deal with unhappy and unwilling workers on the service side of things who take over your accounts once you sell them. They will divert all problems to you, which then takes time away from actually selling.

The top sales reps are people who have deals fall into their laps and unfortunately they then get praised and promoted leading to managers that have no idea what the true grind of a sales rep is like.

Overall, just avoid a sales position here. There are better companies out there to sell for and who will pay you just as much, if not more. They have an outdated way of doing things and have no reason to change since their competition in the industry is downright awful. The industry is dirty and known for lengthy contracts, suing former customers, high service charges, and outrageous price increases.

review_title: Had a Horrible Experience with Cintas Recruiter
pros:
Andy Noto, one of Cintas's outside recruiters, contacted me about a great Management Trainee opportunity before it was even posted online

Said they were especially interested in Veterans and those just finishing college which described me to a T
cons:
After attending a meet and greet with the Cintas staff I didn't hear back for about a month until Andy hit me up asking what happened. When I told him that I'd submitted my application and thank you notes but still hadn't heard back, he said he'd call the hiring manager and get back to me, never heard back.

About a week after that, I shot Andy a text asking if all candidates should expect to left in the dark like this. 

In the following conversations, he proceeded to laugh at me and tell me this was my own fault. He made fun of me for having been let go from a position before. He pointed out that not hearing back is as just as good being told we're not interested, thankfully most companies in my experience don't operate that way.

After mentioning that I'd be leaving this review, the insults started flying in faster, he left me no less than a dozen text messages and called me from 2 different numbers trying to reach me personally.

I have to admit that I've never been treated so poorly by somebody that was doing their job, I'd hate to think that other Veteran candidates are going through this same experience.

review_title: Great place to work but underpaid.
pros: Cintas is a great place to start a career. There is a lot of opportunities for advancement. Overall fairly compensated for an entry-level position.
cons: Upper management makes a lot of money when the partners on the road are doing all hard work. Pay is low.

pros: Four day work week. Being out on your own without someone breathing down your throat. Four day work week!
cons:
-Unstable pay.
-Pay plans that are always changed & restructured for the companies gain,not yours.
-Health care costs go up every year with benefits that fall.
-Trucks ALWAYS break down, very little to no maintenance done on any of them.
-Poor management. This seems to be the trend from the corporate level down, take a look on this site, you will definitely see a pattern.
-You will be left on your own to explain why you don't have any product for your customer, don't expect management to help you. Trucks are ALWAYS short product ranging from clothes (yes they loose clothes) mats, rags, towels, mops, etc.....basically what the customer pays for. 
-Sales people will lie lie lie and you will have to pick up the pieces, it's usually not pretty! Most of the time they will overstock/sell products to get their commission percentage up but the driver almost always takes a hit in pay.

This is what Cintas boils down to......
*It is all about the bottom line here. They get as much as they can for as little as possible. (This should be their motto.)
*You're just a number. Don't think for a minute you're not!
* If you really care about the job & the customer you're going to be miserable. If you are ruthless, have no morals and have extreme patience then give it a shot, it could be for you.

Look, the economy is terrible right now & if you need a job, take it. The pay can be good at some times but there are a lot of factors way out of your control to keep it good. Do not expect it to stay the same as it's a commission based salary..........I would strongly recommend to keep your options open & the resumes out there, it is very easy to feel stuck & hopeless after a while.

review_title: What a corrupt, money hungry, shareholders first, Evil Empire (Corporation)
pros: Four day work week, four day work week, four day work week. The less time at this job the better!!!
cons:
Every aspect of being a driver at this job is a con, unless you are a personal friend of someone in management or you kiss the pimples of off managements ass!

Let's put together a list of true aspects of the SSR position at Cintas

1. Your truck will break down and not occasionally. You will break down because this cheap ass company doesn't maintain anything on their fleet. Their main focus is to keep the appearance up & thats it. The routine oil change wasn't even done. This doesn't sound to bad...right? Sit on the clock & get paid... right? not then, they called you "salesmen" you didn't get paid any extra & most of the time they would tow a truck to you, at that point you would have to cross load everything then finish your route hours later. I believe Cintas has to pay overtime now after losing a large class action law suite for not paying employees properly. 

2. Your pay will change for many different reasons. One would be loss of an account. It may be your own fault but not usually. If a very large account goes belly up, defaults on payment or leaves for any reason a large part of your pay goes with it. After you feel the affects in your pay, Cintas tells you to sell more at other accounts. Remember you're a salesman! Another way would be Cintas frequently changed goals, incentives, bonus pay, or the overall pay plan and pretty much changed anything pay related anytime they pleased 
At one point drivers that covered a far distance were paid more to cover the lack of earning ability due to distance. That was removed & fair was not part of the equation.

3. Product: Never had a full days worth of it. Missing products from uniforms, towels, paper products, soaps, mats and most supplies the customer pays for. You were never to credit a customer for this. If you could lie your way out of it every time, that was good enough for Cintas! Most drivers had morals and made it up the next day but you were short product for those customers & cycle continued.


The bottom line with Cintas is it's a corporation and the bottom line is most important. Not the customers or employees. They have things called "spirit day" and try to impose a "family like videos" that get rammed down your throat but it's smoke and mirrors. If you're not ripping off a customer with their sales promotions you better be an ass kisser! The benefits went from good to ok to go get your own.

Here's what most drivers said Cintas stood for: Constantly In Need of Towels And Supplies. 

Most of our customers learned that saying the hard way.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
The only positives are having a job and having benefits. 
Unfortunately i cannot add anything else that would be positive about this job or company
cons:
Negatives at this job:
- Customer service reps are actually account manager but this means they only have to pay them less than $15/hour instead of a salary of $40k plus
- You get only promoted if you are on their "like" list. It does not matter how hard you work or how good you are at your job. you can get promoted within 2 months though you know absolutely nothing but you are a favorite
- if you are "lucky" to get promoted into management you will work 60 + hours for $42k
- While the account specialists are working in a frenzy making all the bonus money and awards, they will never see a penny of it but management will receive all that money
- Management does not even bother to talk to anyone unless they want something from you or yell at you
- Higher national management told account specialists that they are not worthy of a bonus just like the janitor but can work their way up if they want to make money
- Management will almost daily order lunches for themselves with company money while the rest of the company is offered the left overs after they are done
- the typical turn over rate of about 80 employees in the whole building is at least 15 employees per six months period. There is a reason there are job opening all the time.
- understaffed and overworked while management has free lunches among themselves.
- not a single day of sick time or vacation during the first year
- supposedly supporting the spartan way: which is true among the "lower" employees who do not get rewarded for anything while management travels big and eats steak
- 3% salary increase a year. 
- they will tell you during your interview how easy it is to be promoted and how they are posting jobs all the time because the branch is growing so rapidly. The branch is growing but employees that quit can't even be replaced fast enough because the next one quit already.

pros:
-4 Day work week for SSRs
-Okay benefits
-SSRs are allowed to be independent
cons:
I spent almost 5 years at Cintas.  I was a top performer at my location, and easily advanced to the position of Route Trainer.  After 3.5 years of being there, the culture began to change.  It became less about customer satisfaction, and more about "hitting your numbers".  Every week, "numbers" were pounded into our heads, meanwhile customer approval ratings of Cintas were plummeting as evidenced by the poor customer survey results.  

The numbers game not only affects customers, but it also affects SSRs.  On a routine basis, I was constantly short product my customers needed.  Items such as soap, toilet paper, paper towels that the customer pays for were out of stock.  The reason given by the plant manager was that he has a budget, and can't order those items.  So I then had to go out on route and deal with angry customers (rightfully so) who don't understand why they are paying Cintas for a service if Cintas can't keep the items they need in stock.  

In addition to product shortages, I constantly battled against missing garments for customers.  On a daily basis, I would discover I was missing entire sets of uniforms for customers that I had picked up the previous week.  Again, angry customers wanting to know why the "Uniform People" can't keep track of their uniforms.  

I informed management of these issues many times, and there were always promises of it getting fixed, but nothing was ever done.  I expressed my frustration to my manager clearly, many times over.  Either he didn't care, or didn't want to put forth the effort to fix the issues.  Either way, enough was enough and I left voluntarily.  The stress and frustration just isn't worth it.

pros: direct deposit, medical, dental and vision,
cons: These people will work you until you break. They will add more stops to your route and don't care if you have to work longer because they will just fire you if you complain too much. They will make you feel like you are weak if you complain. They have old trucks that the new comers get that are poorly maintained and need to be put out of their misery. Basically just come in do your job and suck it up because they don't care if you get hurt. As a new comer you will get the worst routes and break you back for pennies on the dollar when you work out the money you make vs the hours you work and little sleep because you are always trying to catch up for the week. Do yourself a favor and steer clear of this place. Working construction in the dead of summer is better than this place of misery and suffering. God forbid you try and schedule a doctor or dentist appointment during the week (you know when they are normally open) these Cintas Management people lose their minds that you have all of a sudden become unreliable.  God forbid I try and take care of my health right?

pros: Flex able with hours as long as you get 40 a week. Hourly people are generally nice. Free uniform service.
cons: Upper management has no idea about the state of moral of the hourly partners. If they see that you can do your job good they give you some one ellses job also till you are doing the work of four people.

pros: Pros are few and far between. Willing to train despite your background; they look for a skill set which is better than most companies who only want degrees with no background to show for it.
cons:
High turnover, micro management, poor managerial skills. Despite what they say, all they care about are numbers, they don't care about you as an employee, whatsoever. They hide the truth from the application and interview. Originally hired as an Accounts Receivable Clerk, only to be forced to become AR AND receptionist AND data entry, and anything else in the office that they need.  The pay doesn't come close to the workload. Salary review is a joke... literally .25 cents a year.

Managers that don't want to pick up the slack when people are out yet they won't hire an additional office partner to help balance the already overwhelming workload. Vacation use is questioned...and DENIED because there aren't enough partners to work customer service even though it's not even your job. The office manager is supposed to pick up the slack so the others can work and they refuse.

Office hours strictly 8-5; you can't schedule doctor appointments, events, etc and stay later or come early to make up your time because partners don't have personal lives, apparently. Meanwhile, management just ups and leaves whenever they want at the drop of a dime to be with their families or anything they have personal to do. Reprimanding management for problematic behaviors because of favoritism is expected.

Management does sneaky, underhanded things to their partners. Hiding employee's final paychecks because the GM doesn't like when ppl leave to better themselves, racist, taking photos of employees who work two jobs (which is stalking )to make sure they're where they say they are and can't work OT, the list goes on. They'll lie and manipulate the rules to cover themselves when they do something wrong and YOU have to pay for it. Going against attendance policy and making their own rules, only to double back and write you up when they originally said it was okay to contact them a certain way if something happens.

If you speak out against or question anything, you will forever be a black sheep and can't advance. And certainly not when they know you're right and won't accept it. Honesty and integrity is all the CEO preaches but they don't follow it AT ALL.  I have never worked for a more dishonest and untrustworthy company. I have come to hate Cintas with  every fiber of my being. The day I can quit can't come soon enough.

pros: The work hours are reasonable

Health insurance premium is HIGH and has HIGH deductibles. This has been a BIG step backward for me!! Also hours were cut back to 32/week

job_title: Service Manager in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Great benefits package, PTO isn’t too bad (must request time off 2 weeks in advance).  Management has ability to spend time on the road with drivers.
cons: Terrible upper management, never have products, SSRs are always forced to short customers their product, managers are treated poorly by supervisors, Cintas trucks are unsafe / old / no heat or AC.  Turn over is a revolving door of new partners.

pros: Don't take the job. You will be disappointed, very disappointed. Selling soap door to door does not get you what they are promising you.
cons: They promise a lot. They won't tell you the benefits (car, phone, etc.) don't kick in until a certain point. They won't tell you it's 100% cold calling and every territory has been worked over by the previous suckers. They will avoid talking about turnover rates at all costs. You will be asked to work past 6PM weekly. If it's not your first gig ever, it's not for you. You sell soap door to door.

pros: Benefits are ok. Changed to PTO if you can ever manage to use it and not made to feel guilty about taking days you earned off
cons:
Where do I even start?  This company is awful to work for. At least at my location.  Surely other locations are not nearly as dysfunctional or the whole company would go belly up. Everything st my location starts with the arrogant and incompetent GM who only got the job because of race and a lot of kissing up to the right people. You are treated like a number despite how hard you work or how many years you have put into the place and how much you have done for the location and will be fired at any point. Management will make up lies about you and fake documentation to get you out of the door if you rock the boat. There is a culture of fear and paranoia that goes through the whole location brought on because of management’s own paranoia.  Relax not everyone is trying to get you!  Maybe the GM is so paranoid because he knows he is under qualified for the job in the first place. Turn over is 50% no lie and people are dropping like flies. Morale is so low partners literally wake up wondering if they can just stay in bed because they got fired. 

The pressure on the ssr is immense because of unrealistic sales goals that are based on fictional numbers. Cintas pretends to care about customers but gouges then at every opportunity. Customers are at a breaking point and SSRs bear the brunt of their frustrations.  The SSRs are in a no win situation and are forced to stick it to their customers to hit their numbers else they will be fired for underperformance.  

There is zero loyalty in the company despite how many years you put in. If you rock the boat you will be shown the door even if you have a stellar record. They will make up lies about you and try to tarnish your reputation to make it seem like it is your fault. 

They will also work you to the bone.  Can’t tell you how many people at the location have gotten high blood pressure from the job. People are literally popping Xanax just to get through the day!

The income for SSRs is not stable. If they choose to do a route split you can lose 10-20k per month in volume which equates to about 1000-2000 dollars a month. Also because your sales goals go up each year your bonuses and commissions actually go down the longer you are with the company because it gets to a certain point to where the goals and bonuses are not achievable. This is possibly the only company where you can make much less 5 years into the job than you made your first year!  Your pay check shouldn’t go down. 

Management micromanages to the nth degree and gets in the way of business.  All they care about is passing internal audits and being at the top of certain internal rankings. 

Sales and SSRs are under such pressure that they do unethical things like stuffing medical boxes or double selling accounts.  Can’t tell you how many window resets are bogus just so the sales rep can scrape by.  

Pay is ridiculously low and has high volatility. 

Zero work life balance. You work 12 hours a day and go home and become a recluse. 

Meetings about meetings. 

Finally very cheap. Won’t pay for anything to help the front line

pros: 4 day work week, good insurance
cons: Wake up at 345 in the morning to drive 45 min to plant. Very early start every day. Allot of responsibility is put on an ssr driver.. Route grouth, contract renuals, inventory management. It's allot more than just delivering uniforms

Co-workers were very unfriendly at my location.

review_title: Whistleblower: Do not take this job, it is an absolutely nightmare
pros: Working at Cintas in sales looks good on a resume, thats really about it.
cons:
There is much to share here from my personal experience. 

1. you will treated as a second class citizen at Cintas: None of the other divisions care about deep clean. You do not have anywhere near the amount of administrative support as the other divisions. your compensation is way lower than the other divisions. you are expected to track all of your own paperwork and billing (no other roll has to do that) and if you can't provide 100% documentation you do not receive your comission 

Unrealistic sales goals and implementation: they will try to tell you that an average deal sells for 5k... more like 1-2k. you are expected to hit sales goals that reflect the average job being 5k. Heres the kicker though, even if you sell all the necessary business, for you to get paid it has to be installed. This means you have to fit all those jobs on the schedule for that month. you also have to share the schedule/resources with another rep as well as the market managers "recurring business" It is also important to know that the market manager has full say of what goes on the schedule and when.

Overworked/non existent technicians: Our branch had technicians quit left and right. if the techs can't work, they expect you to go out on the job and help to get the job done (unpaid). if the jobs don't install, you don't get paid and its still reflected in your goals.

Used as a stepping stone for people wanting in upper management: This division is used by the ambitious in order to get to the next levels of management. several people have had to be the head of that division in order to get to the next level of management and are now in upper management. They will squeeze you dry, and leave promises of being able to get you to a different division with no follow up action. I had a manager trying to tell me i needed to go on 25 new appointments a week, which is completely unrealistic. When i asked him if he truly thought this was realistic, he told me that I just wasn't working hard enough, even though this boss never had to sell this product in this division.

Complete unawareness of the product and sales process from other divisions management: my favorite was when they said that "FS and Uniform are a harder sale than deep clean is", which is unbelievably false. Seeing as how Cintas is one of the few companies who can consistently fill orders of supplies without hiccups, the majority of people use them simply off this fact. With deep clean, you have local competitors everywhere who are willing to do it for 1/3 of the price without a major difference in end result (most of the time), you are automatically disqualified from many large job bids due to Cintas' "non union" status, and frankly even if you did win a big contract the resources deep clean has would in no way be able consistently meet the terms of the contract. 

If your operations team is unable to complete the jobs management will still put you on a plan: If the schedule is full or you don't have the technicians to complete jobs, the management will still put you on a performance plan.

ask these questions while in an interview (but if you do they will probably cut you, Cintas doesn't really like "Free thinkers")

1. what happened to the last rep here? what about the one before that? the one before that?

2. what would you say the retention rate for the division as a whole has been?

3. Can you direct me to some people who used to work in this division so I can ask further questions regarding their experience? (if they're still employees the may not tell you the truth directly, but their body language will say it all)

4. what has the staffing been like for this position on the ops side? Is there enough people employed for this division to run sufficiently?

pros: Interacting with customers on a daily basis
cons: Awful situation ssrs are being put into

pros: Pay and benefits.  I do believe that these are the major reasons most people take a job.  Cintas is a good company and it has alot of great things to offer

review_title: Ignore the urge to accept the Job Offer!
pros: Excellent Medical Benefits.  Once a partner is hired, medical benefits are available 30 days after employment.  Additionally, there is no medical screening or questions asked regarding your health status.
cons: If you enjoy a CULTure that promotes eat, drink, sleep cintas,  then this is the place to be.  You are treated like a robot.  Literally!  This company is only interested in "what have you done for me lately?"  The Management style is very old school.  The dictatorship is felt on a daily basis:  the poop truly does run down the hill.  The business side of the American culture has changed and Cintas has yet to adjust to that.  This company is all about perception.  You know the saying "If it sounds like a duck, it must be a duck."  Well, highly educated people can figure out what is behind  this curtain.  Finally, there is a lot of mini-training sessions that a partner signs off on.  The PERCEPTION of this is that this company is educating their employees.  How nice, or is it?  It's clear this company is covering all angles of malfunction that may occur with a partner so the company is not liable.  For instance, when an employee parks in their parking lot, they have to SIGN a policy that states Cintas is not liable for damage to the vehicle while parked on THEIR premises.  Wow, this Cintas policy should make you feel like a "PARTNER."  (partner is a coined term by the CEO of Cintas and is referenced as  an employee to make you feel connected)

pros: great company, great benefits great pay, great people. Great company to work for and can move up very fast if you show improvement

job_title: Order Fulfillment in Bedford Park, IL
pros: None ..nothing, nada, zilch, RUN
cons: I am so glad to be gone from this hell hole. They should call their employees prisoners not partners. This is the most degrading job I have ever had. The salaried people and the route drivers won't see it this way necessarily because they are considered the bread and butter of this company. The Distribution center, customer service and poor order fulfillment is the pits. They micro manage everything. If you have to use the restrooms outside of your two breaks and lunch, its a problem. If  you talk ...moreso in order fulfillment, its a problem. If you get up and talk, upper management will walk around to see what you are doing, to try to intimidate you from socializing. Their systems don't work, their workflow process don't work. Nothing works. So many mangers and what for? None of them are educated, smart, logical or classy. They  treat their employees like indentured servants. They expect you to bend over backwards for them and they change your schedule at a moment notice, cut your hours, then expect you to sign up for over time later.  Management walks around and ask  you "Isn't this company amazing"?  Like you should be happy to be working here, and being treated like this. I heard management say, she doesn't care about those who left or who are leaving because they are meeting their numbers regardless. What type of management says that openly in the middle of the call center, so employees can hear?  The employees who have been there the longest, are tired of this place and no there is no advancement, but they feel their is no hope, they don't think there is anything better. They are fearful of not having a job so the conform to this communism work life. If you are a new hire, they will not tell you that training is very little and not comprehensive. They will not tell you, you won't get vacation for a year and then its only five days. No personal time. There is no work life balance here. Also, this company is a multi billion dollar company; but they don't give a 401K match?? What??? They have this KPI system that they live by, but no one can explain how it really works. that's because the manager that introduced this system, resigned. This place is a horrible place for  anyone but it is really horrible to minorities, minorities not just saying African Americans, Polish, Hispanic etc. and they knowingly treat people unfair. I am so glad to be gone. It was the worst job I've ever had ....If you are interviewing for order fulfillment, or customer service run your butt off!!!

review_title: Good experience overall until the end

review_title: FA & Safety SSR position is Horrible!!!
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Houston, TX
pros: You can take your van home and avoid tolls, $50 phone allowance
cons:
Everything is a con in the first aid and safety division in Houston.  All of the corporate character they preach is lies. They want you to rip off your customers and stuff their first aid cabinets. Every month they come up with a new ridiculous focus item to stuff in the cabinets. Last month is was liquid bandage, hand lotion, pain away (excedrin), and glucose. They claimed those items were immparitve to the health of people with diabetes. In reality the only thing that would actually help is the glucose. It’s funny they force you to sell two servings of glucose for $15!!! $.50 Pixy sticks is literally the exact same ingredient.

Anyways, that’s just the unethical aspect of the company. The 2nd problem with Cintas is that they don’t care about the employees. In their mind they can easily replace their SSRs. They also act like they treat us amazing and boast abouy their  16k salar they pay us. It’s laughable. You make commission on top of that, most people are making under 40k bc they keep splitting people’s routes. There used to be SSRs that would make 55k plus, heck some people made 65k-75k, but once you make good money they will split your route. I seriously know people who can barely pay their mortgage now bc of their route splits. Our turnover rate was 66% a year ago, it’s probably even worse now. One average we lose at least one SSR a month.

Management acts like we are an ethical company but they secretly are pushing us to sell things to our customers they don’t need.

Not only that, but the internet is so much better for our customers. I feel like a used car salesmen when I sell a box of DayQuil  for $65 when you can buy the same box on amazon or staples for $15. Literally everything we sell is marked up 600% bc our corporate is super greedy. Also, when you lower the price just a little bit you go from making 11% commission to 5%. So if you want to feed your family you have to sell it at the rip off price.

review_title: Only got 1 star because I couldn't give it 0.
pros: I have NONE at all. This place is driving me crazy. The workers are the LAZIEST people I have EVER worked with. The managers don't care at all OR do anything about it (unless you're close with them). We are all under paid, they make you have a job title that pays less and give you a harder position. Don't forget the 10c raise (25 if you're REALLY lucky)! That's after not missing a day or being late for over a year. We have a high turn over rate on "Partner's" They bring in temps when we get behind, then let them go before the 90 days is up or when we slow back down (usually the holidays) You notice you go on youtube and type in cintas and they don't allow comments. They know the truth and they do not care. We literally are just a number to them. Not everyone is treated equally what so ever. Only people who get a bonus are the ssr's and upper management. They don't care about Production at all.Score %100 on an audit and get a pizza party (if you're production)while they all get a big bonus check! I would not recommend this place to ANYONE. I am a VERY hard worker and I am treated like I do nothing and the crazy thing about it is that the bad workers get more appreciation . I could go on and on believe me. I am out of work now and need to stop thinking about that place. I hope this helps people, this is a very real review from a very HONEST and HARD working current employee. This was the only place I could get this off my chest.
cons: Everything about that place is a con, it's a paycheck that's it.

pros: Fortune 500 company, cheap and reliable health benefits, good 401k plan
cons: You are overworked and underpaid, you will work on access of 65 to 80 hours a week and the salary does not compensate for it. Your sold on a bonus plan that sounds great but, isnt really realistic unless your fudging the numbers to make it. The sales department is not held accountable for anything. They over-sale accounts and over promise different item on both new and current customers, mid and upper level management sees it and because the number looks good they say NOTHING and make excuses and point the finger everyone but the originator of the issue. There is no consistency in the postion. You make a schedule and the moment one person calls off your running a route, following up with a driver about a issue, making customer service calls dealing with production issues/sales issues. The position is not a desirable job PERIOD.

job_title: Fire Service Technician in Ledgewood, NJ
pros:
There are some good people that come in with great attitudes and high expectations of what is promised only to be thrown in the mix of churning out numbers and ever inflating service charges and nickel and dime price gouging becomes the stick that stirs the pot of job justification for code compliance. Meaning, your raise and bonuses are based upon performance but they slam you with accounts which, actually have a fraction of the compensation being paid to techs and 100% of the work to be completed perfectly. Now, while it appears that your voices are being heard and they care about your well being, unless you’re sucking up to or kissing serious donkey by laughing at stupid stories from cold, soulless and spineless people, most all of them anyway-not all, or watching management get younger and younger with inexperienced kids that have no life experience ,but a college degree or an alma mater that they personal attended also, you most likely will go nowhere. Management will dangle achievement, growth, success,pacing,KPIs,bonuses and then lie to your face when you question anything. I was a top performer for nearly 11 years until I wised up and broke free. 
It is a twisted place to work and you will most likely, not definitely, go nowhere because you’re constantly chasing down what they said they will help you achieve. You have people in power who are just voracious and lifeless, with the exception of a few, that just care about their own growth and bonuses. Condescending, ignorant and immature with leveraged work attitudes of writing you up if you don’t do what they say. 
Absolutely ridiculous and I feel absurd how the corporation can bend the work laws as far as they can without being held accountable for their oftentimes scrupulous behavior. 
They will give you breakfasts and team building activities and send you to cookie cutter corporate learning seminars...nonsense, 
The pay is fine if you’re not on commission. After 11 years, I got the heck out. 
If they kept up the same work experience after 6-12 months and cared about your personal development, then it would be a great place to work.
cons:
Great place to work!!!!
See the confusion? That’s what working here is like.  Good luck.

review_title: The Spirit is not the Difference
pros:
Pros:
Uniforms - Like the men's pants, plenty of pockets to put your materials in.
Benefits? - I added this because the people here say the benefits are good. The job i work for now has even better benefits.

Training - I added this in here because you have the ability to be cross-train in different positions. Your pay will stay the same, regardless that a specific role may pay more than another. My advice, make goals, get your experience, add it to your resume, and find another job who will pay you your worth. Cintas on your resume has some weight when looking for another job.
cons:
Cons: Where do I begin

Incentives - A free candy bar for exceeding your fellow partners expectation! They are enacting incentives at this facility due to the revolving door but even what they have in place is not enough with the competitive markets all around Groveport. No bonuses are given for performances for both associates and coordinators. This is not the place you want to be if you have work at other warehouses that values their employees.

Pay - Cintas has a spartan mentality, and they will not pay you to stay competitive in the market. The location I work, Cintas is in a highly competitive warehouse market and they will not find the right quality of people to sustain operations for long. We all signed on the dotted line, but all of us hired on was told about the vast opportunities the company offers to move up and assuming how large Cintas is, you feel there is hope. It’s very slow. the first-year raises were highly disappointing thus began the revolving door.

Pay pt. 2 - Just because one location in your company pays less for similar job functions does not mean the cost of living is the same in this location. Each department has their own base pay, regardless of experience, you all start off at the same amount. If you don't want to pay more for your workers, just leave the area once your contract is up. You won’t be miss.

Opportunities - Slow, unless you are right out of high school, you may have the fortitude to wait several years at a chance for a good opportunity. Be wary though, applying internally does not mean anything, you will still wait months for a call back, if they even grant that. I know people who applied internally, and their resume was never viewed from HR.

Prorated time off – Good/ or bad. You are immediately allowed to use your time off as soon as you are hired vs some companies’ standard of waiting 30-90 days. I have seen people hired in first day, see what the job entitles, then start calling off to use up there PTO, then quit.

Disciplinary Action- Management claims that they aren't babysitters, and with that attitude, the actions of their 'partners' show. You have gossipers, and complainers who travel from each department who aren't happy, and with the amount of people in this location, the word spreads fast.

Disciplinary Action pt.2 - The 'partners' who are the root cause of discomfort in the warehouse are not discipline enough for change. They have zero action plans thus the entire warehouse morale stays low. You will discover who they are first day easily for they will approach you to walk out the door cause it "sucks here."

HR - There is a comment about how disarray HR is, that is 100% true. There infrastructure is weak, causing mass confusion with their 'partners'. What you hear today and sign off on can change one day later (seriously). HR is very slow with processes and you will have constant anxiety on whether something was done correctly. 

Training - While I made a positive comment about training, there is also a negative. The training can be limited due to the lack of experience with management. Since they do not want to babysit and don't have SOP's straighten out and finalize, you are forced to make mistakes, it’s okay because no disciplinary actions are taken. One lady had been written up almost once a day, 4-5 times a week by Quality and nothing was done. She got her own self fired for doing something extraordinary out of context.

Quality - Bad products coming in and out the door and quality is overwork and underpaid. There Inbound person after 1 year had enough, put in his notice and left. The customer complaints will roll in because production management thinks they know more about quality due to their experiences on the rental side of the business. Quality management is non-existent from what I seen in the warehouse, they just had quality associates.

Management - Management lacks the experience to handle their team. There "were not babysitter" attitudes makes for an uncomfortable/hostile environment. With HR not taking a unbiased/anonymous approach, you will be left speaking in uncomfortable positions, sometimes with the management person in the room. The walls in the rooms are paper-thin so when gossipers see you go in the office, they will pretend to go in looking for something, then spread the word of what you said.

Culture - The CEO would have a full investigation team out in this location for how badly the locations culture is. No PR speech can cover up the mass destruction that is taken place within the infrastructure of this company. Wasting money on throwing up quotes and timelines on the wall and management not showing that they live and breathe these core values to there 'partners' is the reason why this location, and plenty more are tanking.

pros: Lots of overtime available due to poor scheduling and lack of planning.  Benefits are great for a single person with no kids and plenty of outside network facilities.  You fail up. If you are bad at your job then expect promotions. If your too good they will forget about you and keep you doing what your doing.
cons:
Cintas will buy out a profitable company, absorb  them and then neglect any clients that the previous company had. Clients complain as soon as tech arrives about office personnel; either poor scheduling, no quotes, little to no communication with clients, or are rude and unprofessional with client. 

Will schedule hours for both night and day hours in same week. (Day monday  and tuesday and night wed-fri) Managment expects 12 day notice for days off but schedule jobs only 3 days at a time. Finish a job on wed and not know wtf your doing rest of the week or anytime in the future until a late late night text telling you to be an hour and a half away from your home at 5am.  Will schedule you for jobs as far away from your home as possible when other helpers live down the street from that job site.  

Dont expect pay increase unless threatening to leave.  

Expected to drive own vehicle with no reimbursements.  No gas card, no toll tag, expect to put 50k miles on car in 1yr.


Management treats everyone as if they are speaking to their children. Managment takes no responsibility as to why they lose accounts and blame anyone and everyone including client.  Management favorite phrase, "that's the nature of the beast; take it or leave it."  

Buys up other competitors just to neglect accquired accounts until they leave and dont have to deal anymore.  

ZERO advancement: was told to apply for a better position in another part of company such as floor mates or emergency lighting!

Had to schedule own 1yr evaluation close to 2nd year.
